STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 22, 2021
Noelle Bair
Allegan County DHHS
3255 122nd Street
Allegan, MI 49010
RE: License #: CP030200937
Allegan County DHHS
3255 122nd Street
Allegan, MI 49010
Dear Ms. Bair:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 10/18/2021-
10/22/2021. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the MDHHS
Policy and MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be
noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your
contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP030200937
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Demetrius Starling, Designee
Designee:
Name of Facility: Allegan County DHHS
Facility Address: 3255 122nd Street
Allegan, MI 49010
Facility Telephone #: (269) 673-7700
Original Issuance Date: 11/01/1990
Service Types: Certify Homes for Foster Care Licensure
Receive Children for Placement in Foster Care
Supervise Independent Living
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): October 18-22, 2022

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the
following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months
after the staff member assumes his or her current
responsibilities. After the initial evaluation, a written
evaluation shall be conducted each year.
2 of 11 employee files reviewed contained performance evaluations completed
outside of the required timeframe.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
from the American Heart Association or the American Red
Cross or other institution approved by the department.
1 of 6 files of licensed foster homes reviewed contained documentation of expired
first aid/CPR training.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d)Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e)All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
family, including information about siblings who do not
reside in the foster home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
Receipt of this information is documented by foster parent
signature on the Initial Placement Outline (DHHS-3307) on a
4

date prior to or at the time of placement as required per FOM
722-03 p.12 & 722-03D p.8
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
required information was provided before or at the time of placement/re-placement.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child:
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
medical care.
Receipt of this information is documented by the presence of
the Consent to Routine, Non-Surgical Medical Care Medical
Authorization card (DHS-3762) dated before or at the time of
placement.
1 of 8 open foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that the foster
parent was provided with medical authorization at the time of placement.
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each
child and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and
at least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
1 of 10 total case files reviewed (8 FC & 2 IL) contained one service plan that was
completed 3 days after the due date.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/23/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/28/2020
10/1/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/19/19
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service
worker and the youth in independent living at least once
each month at a youth's place of residence.
5

2 of 2 open files of youth in IL placements reviewed contained documentation
indicating that not all monthly face-to-face contacts were occurring at the youth’s
place of residence.
R 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum
supervision:
(b) At monthly intervals, ensure that the youth is
complying with the terms of the contract required by R
400.125010, continues to reside in a safe and acceptable
environment, and is managing expenditures.
For YAVFC youth this is documented through the completion of
the Young Adult Monthly Visit Report (DHS 1295) youth as
required per FOM 722-16 p. 14.
1 of 2 open files of youth placed in IL placements did not contain documentation to
verify that the youth was complying with the requirements on a monthly basis.
R 400.12510 Independent living contract.
(2) The agreement shall be signed and dated by the youth
and the social service worker. The contract shall be
reviewed and updated at least once every 90 calendar days
and a copy provided to the youth.
1 of 2 open files of youth living independently did not contain any contracts.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/23/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/28/2020
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Policy violation. Please note
that there are additional MDHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional MDHHS Policy
requirements except for the following:
SRM 200 Personnel Training
Security Awareness Training is required to be taken within
six months of working in a position with CW-CHRI access
and every two years thereafter. CPAs are responsible for
ensuring all personnel with CHRI access completes SAT
timely. SAT certificates must be maintained in all employee
6

personnel files and/or their LMS transcripts to confirm
completion of training
2 of 4 employees required to complete the training did not do so timely.
FOM 722-03B RELATIVE PLACEMENT SAFETY SCREEN
(p.12 -14)
The MDHHS-5770 Relative Placement Safety Screen, is
used to examine basic qualifications of a prospective
caregiver and to identify immediate safety concerns in the
caregiver's home. The DHHS-5770 must be completed and
approved prior to, but no more than 30 calendar days
before a child's placement. All MDHHS-5770's must be
completed in MiSACWIS.
The MDHHS-5770 must be reviewed and approved by a
supervisor prior to placing a child with an unlicensed
relative.
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained MDHHS-5770 that were not
reviewed and approved by a supervisor prior to the placement of children in
unlicensed relative homes.
FOM 722-03C OLDER YOUTH: PREPARATION, PLACEMENT, AND
P. 1 DISCHARGE
Life Skills Assessment - The Casey Life Skills Assessment
must be completed within 90 days of a youth turning 14,
and annually thereafter. For youth who are 14 or older when
they enter care, the assessment should be completed
within 90 days of entering care.
For youth who are placed in residential, it is the residential
case worker who ensures the Casey Life Skills Assessment
if completed.
Placement in independent living may be an acceptable
living arrangement for youth 16 years or older. Prior to
placement in independent living, the caseworker must
assess the youth, with the Casey Life Skills Assessment, as
being prepared for independent living and demonstrate a
pattern of mature decision making.
7

1 of 2 files of youth living independently did not contain documentation that the
Casey Life Skills Assessment was completed annually as required due to the youth’s
age.
FOM 722-03E PLACEMENT EXCEPTION REQUESTS AND APPROVALS
Caseworkers must complete a placement exception request
(PER) when there is a need to waive placement standards
to maintain sibling and caregiver bonds or to meet the
medical, emotional, and psychological needs of children in
care. PERs must be completed, reviewed, and approved in
MiSACWIS.
When verbal approval for a PER has been given prior to
placement, documentation and approval within MiSACWIS
must be completed within 30 calendar days from the date of
the verbal approval.
2 of 8 open foster care case files reviewed contained PER’s that were not approved
within MiSACWIS in 30 days of verbal approval.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/1/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/19/19
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
P. 5 & 12 & 16
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan
(ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due
date. Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business
days prior to a planned change of placement or no later
than three business days after an unplanned placement
change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case
closure date or one business day after unplanned court
ordered dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting
Report, is used to capture family demographics, FTM
logistical information, needs, strengths, action steps,
safety concerns and the safety plan, and any
8

recommendations made for the family during the FTM. The
DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MiSACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days
of the FTM.
5 of 10 total open case files reviewed (8FC & 2 IL) were missing required FTM
documentation. The citation included FTM’s not held for service plan development
and placement changes as well as missing FTM reports for FTMs documented to
have been held.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
9/23/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/28/2020
10/1/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/19/19
FOM 722-08A ONGOING CASE SERVICE PLANS - AGENCY SIGNATURES
P. 30
Prior to finalizing, the caseworker and supervisor must
review the case service plan and all linked assessments
and treatment plans during a face-to-face meeting. Case
service plan review may occur during monthly case
consultation (supervision).
The supervisor must review and approve the service plan
within 14 calendar days of the report date.
1 of 11 total open case files reviewed (8FC & 2 IL) contained 1 service plan that was
not approved within 14 days.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-09)
9/23/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/28/2020
10/1/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/19/19
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
P. 9 & 10
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are
placed apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court-ordered caregivers.
9

Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check
yes or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service
Plan and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review,
and I will have the opportunity to express my
disagreement with the Case Service Plan and Parent
Agency Treatment Plan when the information is
presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign
the treatment plan, the caseworker must identify, and
document actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or
youth’s participation in service planning and compliance
with the treatment plan.
CI-17-099 All treatment plans with a report date of August 1,
2017, or later must have signatures from all appropriate
case members within 30 days of the report date.
6 of 10 total open case files reviewed (8FC & 2IL) contained PATP’s that did not
have all required signatures present.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-08C)
10/1/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/19/19
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
P. 1
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
10

Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
1 of 13 total case files reviewed (8 open FC, 2 closed FC, 2 open IL, 1 closed IL) did
not contain all action summaries completed as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-09C)
9/23/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/28/2020
10/1/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/19/19
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child/youth's placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are
not required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must
be current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the
child's current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another caseworker must sign and
date the medical passport verifying that s/he has sought
and obtained the necessary information under law and
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
(MDHHS) policy.
11

Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties
is documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and
dated signature page into the Health Profile section.
3 of 11 total open files reviewed (8FC & 2IL) did not contain all required medical
passports.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED (previously cited as 722-09C)
9/23/2020 RENEWAL, CAP APPROVED 10/28/2020
10/1/2019 INTERIM, CAP APPROVED 11/19/19
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 When a youth is placed in the home of a non-respondent parent, that parent
must sign all applicable documents as a relative caregiver.
 If in person visits cannot be conducted due to concerns related to COVID-19, the
case contacts and any applicable reports must include details as to why the visit
could not be done safely.
 All signatures must include the date the document was signed. Caseworkers
must not fill in dates is someone fails to include the date with their signature.
 Caseworkers must document all efforts to obtain signatures, which must include
reasonable effort (ie. more than mailing a document once to a parent or
caregiver)
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
No consultation was requested.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
9/23/2020 RENEWAL inspection report, CAP APPROVED 10/28/2020. The
facility is in compliance with areas of that CAP not identified as repeat
violations during this inspection.
Chief Administrator Assessment – The Chief Administrator Assessment was
reviewed and discussed. The assessment accurately identified areas of non-
compliance.
Interviews – The staff members interviewed reported feeling supported by their
coworkers and superiors. They reported a smooth transition during change in
12

leadership due to regular and continued communication.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety concerns identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
October 22, 2021
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 22, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
